I now produce a certified copy of the prisoner's account—the first credit is £6 10s. on 16th January; after that there are several small amounts—on 11th and morning of 13th June there was £4, and the transactions on that day overdrew it 11d.—on October 4th there was nothing to his credit—fifteen cheques were paid in after there was nothing but lid. on the wrong side of his account.

Cross-examined. Several of your cheques have come in since 13th June, and have been returned dishonoured—on 13th June a fresh cheque book was given to you—if it was not handed to you, it was handed to someone who produced an order signed by you.

By the JURY. We bad references about the prisoner; Mr. M. Freed-lander, 65, Milton Street, City, and L. Persow, 22, Pen ton Street, N.—I presume they were satisfactory—we gave the last cheque-book because
we did not know he was not going to pay more in; there was something when he had it—we charged £2 2s. commission because the account was so small.

HUGH BONNOR (Re-examined). I now produce a certified copy of the prisoner's account—on 4th October £5 was paid in to open the account; there is no other credit since—on the 11th and 13th October he had £4 18s. to his credit, and a cheque was then drawn for £3 10s—on 22nd October he had £1 2s—a cheque was presented on 23rd for £1, leaving 2s. to his balance, and on 24th that 2s. was sent to him in stamps to close the account.

By the JURY. We did not demand references, because we knew he had an account at the Central Bank, Whitechapel; he produced his pass book—we made no inquiries there—he was supposed to have removed—as a rule we do not open accounts under £50—a letter was sent to his address on the 24th enclosing the twenty-four stamps, and saying his account was closed—numerous other cheques signed by die prisoner were presented, some of them were cashed—on 16th October a cheque for £5 10s. was presented and dishonoured, on 21st one for £25, on 23rd one payable to Desser for £5 10s., and on 24th one for £2 18s. 6d.—he drew cheques to the amount of £16 3s., leaving only £5 in the Bank.

ANNIE GUEBTLEB . I live at 105, Oxford Street, East—my husband, Harris Guertler, is a stick-maker—I used to have lodgers—six or seven weeks ago Mr. Benjamin lodged in my house—he was always on business in the country—perhaps he called, or perhaps he did not, so many people called to see the lodgers—I cannot say if I have seen you before—you are not Mr. Benjamin, nor do you look like him; he was a dark man and taller, I suppose, than yon-you do not resemble him at all—I should know him if I saw him—when Mr. Haimsohn came to my premises Benjamin lived there in a little first-floor back room; he had only one room; but he was in the country the first time Mr. Haimsohn came—he asked if there was a person named Benjamin, and I told him yes; he asked nothing more.
Cross-examined. The prisoner never lived in my house.
ROBERT MURPHY (Re-examined). The prisoner gave the name of another witness, Morlitz, of 110, Birch Lane; he declines to attend.

p.hi: The Prisoner, in his defence, stated that he had received the cheques from his partner Benjamin, and that he did not 'know they were wrong, and did not mean to defraud.

div1.p:
GUILTY on the, second, third, fourth and fifth counts —
Twelve Months' Hard Labour.

89.
JAMES ADAMS (23)
, Robbery with violence, with others unknown, on
William Richard Lee, and stealing 7s., his money.

WILLIAM RICHARD LEE . I live at 65, St. John's Street Road, Clerkenwell, and am a hackney-carriage driver—about 12.30 a.m., on 26th October, I went to a coffee-stall on the top of Mount Pleasant, Clerkenwell, and called for a cup of coffee and an egg—I was breaking the egg, when I received a severe blow on my left eye—I turned sharp

round, and saw the prisoner withdrawing his hand—I was mobbed by eight or nine persons, and hustled away from the coffee-stall; two men pinned me behind, and the prisoner put his hand in my right-hand trousers pocket and took oat 7s. in silver, loose—I knew him by sight, and X said, "You can do what you like; I can find you any time"—I was then knocked down; I received a severe kick in the saw which rendered me insensible—I communicated with the police, and afterwards went with them to several houses, and finally to the Exmouth Arms beer-shop, where I saw the prisoner in a room with fifty or sixty others, and I pointed him out—a concert was going on; it was Sunday night—I tapped the prisoner on the shoulder—he got up, and said, "Halloa, old man, how are you?"—I said, "All right;" the policeman informed him he would be charged with assaulting and robbing me—he said, "I never saw the man before in my life"—I only knew him by sight hanging about coffee-stalls—he is the man who robbed me.

Cross-examined. He was sitting in the room with the chairman's hammer in his hand—he was the chairman, I expect—I had been about a minute at the coffee-stall before I was struck—I knew none of the other people there; I know Hubble by sight—he came up soon after I got there; he saw the beginning of it, because I spoke to him before I got a blow—the coffee-stall keeper was there; 1 don't know him; I never went to that coffee-stall before, it is not a nice one; it is in a dark place—the keeper has two big lamps; there is plenty of light, you can see everybody's face as clearly as in this Court—when my arms were pinned the prisoner was right in front of me; I could not see Hubble then—only the prisoner put his hands into my pockets—when I dropped down, being lacked, they all went away—my cab-rank is there-people know me pretty well about there—I had not had any refreshment—I had done fifteen hours' work, and had put my horse and cab away—I did not hear the prisoner say to the police, "I was going to have a cap of coffee at the stall when the prosecutor came and pushed against me; I struck him, and we had a fight"—it is quite untrue that I had any altercation with him, or anybody else at the stall—the coffee-stall keeper is not here.
Re-examined. I had known the prisoner sufficiently well to be able to identify him—I had had no previous altercation with him.

WILLIAM BLIGHT (Detective Sergeant G). About 9.30 on Sunday night, 26th October, I went with Lee to the Exmouth Arms beer-house, and upstairs: a "sing-son?" was going on, and fifty or sixty people were assembled—Lee identified Adams as the man that knocked him down and robbed him the same morning—the prisoner was chairman—I said, "I am a police officer, and shall arrest you for assaulting this man, and robbing him of 7s. at a coffee-stall on Mount Pleasant, about 12.30 on the 26th"—he said, "I never saw this man before"—I took him in custody—on the way to the station he said, "I will tell you the truth. I know the prosecutor, and when I was having a cup of coffee at a stall in Farringdon Road he pushed against me. I asked him what he done that for; he then struck me in the eye, and we had a fight. I never stole his money"—Mount Pleasant is in Farringdon Road—when charged at the station he made no reply.
Cross-examined. The coffee-stall has been there some weeks; the keeper is not here—the prisoner looked surprised when I took him in

custody, and so did the people in the room—I had no trouble in getting him out of the room—the prosecutor was sober when he made the charge at the station—there are no convictions against the prisoner that I know of—he made the statement about the fight of his own accord.

ALFRED HUBBLE . I live at Warner Street. Clerkenwell—soon after midnight on 26th October I went up to the coffee-stall on Mount Pleasant, and called for a cup of coffee and a slice of bread; I was standing by the prosecutor's side—I have known Lee about seven years by sight—I got my coffee, and I looked up and saw the prisoner drive a blow at Lee. which knocked my coffee out of my hands; he hit Lee on the left-hand side—the prisoner has been pointed out to me before as Peggy Adams, a professional boxer, and I know him by sight—then Le was hustled by nine or ten men into the road; I put my coffee down and ran to his assistance and said, "Let him alone, he has not done anything"—some blows were struck at me, and I jumped away from them—they went away and left Lee lying there, and I and another man picked him up and took him across to the other side of the road.

Cross-examined. When I came up to the stall the prisoner was there with the others—the prosecutor had called for his coffee before I got up there; he was breaking his egg—I did not see the prisoner put his hands into the prosecutor's pockets—they were round him—I know none of the other men there.

WILLIAM RICHARD LEE (Re-examined). I had seven shillings in this pocket—I had paid for the coffee out of money in the other pocket—I am certain the money could not have been lost in the scuffle—a minute before it was in my pocket.
NOT GUILTY .

90.
ROBERT FRENCH (27)
, Assaulting
William Blight, a con stable, in the execution of his duty.

WILLIAM BLIGHT (Detective Sergeant G). On 26th October, about 9.30, I had a man in custody in Yardley Street, Clerkenwell, and I had gone about fifty or sixty yards from the beer-house with him when the prisoner came running down the street, without a hat, and caught hold of the prisoner's left arm, which stayed me for a minute; and he said, "You are going no further"—at the same time he held up his hand to some young men coining out of the beer-house, and said, "Come on, lads!"—five or six plain clothes officers were quite close to the young men, and they came no further—Main arrested the prisoner—after he was in custody he said something, I could not hear what—I took the other man to the station—I have no doubt it was the prisoner who caught hold of Adams. (See last case.)

JAMES MAIN (G 197). On this evening I went with Blight to the Exmouth Arms, and saw him arrest Adams—he was conveying him along Yardley Street when the prisoner rushed out of the beer-house, bareheaded, at the head of a number of young men, and ran past me and caught hold of the prisoner's arm, and said, "You are not going to go any further"—he turned half-round and looked towards the others, and shouted, "dome on, lads!"—I sprang forward, and took him in custody—he said, "I only wanted to tell him that if it was anything before half-past twelve I should be a witness for him, as I was with him till then"—five officers were with
Blight and me—we were all in plain clothes—the prisoner and the gang of men would know two of us, but the others stopped outside—when the other officers made their appearance the other men stopped.

WILLIAM EICHABD LEE . I am a hackney carriage driver, of 65, St. John Street Road—I did not see you catch hold of Adams's arm or strike the officer—you took me and the police upstairs at the Exmouth Arms when we came into the bar.

Cross-examined. After the arrest had been effected I saw the prisoner in the house—I followed out—I was a bit in front of Blight, who had Adams in custody—I did not see the prisoner at all, because I was in front, and was not looking; I should not have seen if the prisoner had assaulted Blight.

JAMES ADAMS . I live at 5, Richbell Place, Hanwell Street, Theobald's Road, Holborn—you did not catch hold of my arm while I was outside in custody; no one did except the constable—you called no comrades to assist me—you said, "Go quiet, Jim; I will be down in the morning to see how you get on," and Blight called out to the detectives behind, "Fetch him in"—he did not lay his hands on me.

Cross-examined. The prisoner was at the door when they brought me out of the public-house—I saw him arrested, and I heard him say, "I only wanted to tell him that if it was anything before half-past twelve I was with him"—he had done nothing, although he made that statement.

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence, denied having touched the constable or called to his comrades.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: 91. GEORGE WASHINGTON BUTTERFIEID (45) was indicted for a libel on Harry Hananel Marks.
In consequence of the extreme length of this case, which extended half-way through the following Session, it will be printed in the next part.
